CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Art. 5-3;Violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - award

TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and is serving a prison sentence in colony no . CARDINAL in FAC .

CARDINAL . The applicant was arrested on DATE . He was suspected of unlawful possession of firearms and CARDINAL robberies of local post offices , as well as robbery , triple murder and attempted murder of security officers transporting money . A search was carried out of the applicant 's garage and another location indicated by the applicant ; certain evidence such as coins , guns and gun cartridges were seized . CARDINAL . The applicant 's detention was examined again on DATE and he was remanded in custody on the same grounds . The judge also referred to the applicant 's personality and that he “ had committed several criminal offences within a short period of time ” . Lastly , the judge noted that the period asked for ( DATE ) by the investigating authority was justified by the need to carry out specific investigative measures and to obtain CARDINAL expert reports .

CARDINAL . According to an out - patient psychiatric report dated CARDINAL DATE , the applicant had symptoms of “ an accentuated personality ” prone to gambling ; however , this condition was not considered as requiring treatment or entailing any legal consequences ( see also paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

The ORG has taken due account of the fact that [ the applicant ] has a permanent place of residence , provided positive accounts from his employer and has an underage child in his care .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW , detention of an accused pending investigation should not exceed DATE . It may , however , be extended to DATE . Further extensions to up to DATE are possible only in relation to persons accused of serious or very serious criminal offences , in view of the complexity of the case and if there are grounds justifying detention . An investigator 's request for extension must be approved by the regional prosecutor ( § CARDINAL ) . Further extension of detention beyond DATE and DATE may be authorised only in exceptional circumstances in respect of persons accused of very serious offences , upon an investigator 's request approved by ORG or his deputy ( § CARDINAL ) . Extension of detention beyond DATE is prohibited and the detainee must be released , unless the court decides to extend his detention to the date when the accused has finished studying the case file and the case has then been submitted for trial ( § § CARDINAL and DATE ( CARDINAL ) ) . After the completion of the investigation , an accused kept in detention must be provided with access to the case file DATE preceding the expiry of the maximum period of detention indicated in DATE and CARDINAL ( § CARDINAL ) . If such access was given later than that , the detainee must be released after the expiry of the maximum period of detention ( § CARDINAL ) . If the DATE time - limit was complied with , but was insufficient for the accused , the investigator , with the approval of the regional prosecutor , may request the court to extend the accused 's detention . Such a request should be submitted DATE before the expiry of the maximum detention period ( § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , after a criminal case has been submitted for trial to a court , the latter may , on the party 's request or proprio motu , vary or annul a measure of restraint in respect of the defendant , including placement in custody or detention pending trial . The period of detention pending trial can not normally exceed DATE from the date when the case was submitted to a court and up to delivery of a judgment in the case . However , after the expiry of that period the trial court may extend the detention of a defendant charged with a serious or very serious offence . Each extension must not exceed DATE .
